channel.title: HIS393: Digital History
channel.description: Recent content on HIS393: Digital History

item.title: Assignment 03: Spatial History
item.description: Table of Contents Assignment Getting your assignment, and handing it in Learning Objectives Expectations Due Date: March 03 In class, we made a kind of toy Google Map out of hand-coded HTML, CSS, and Javascript. You will remember it from the course website, from JSBin, and from Github. Your next assignment builds directly from that in-class exercise, and should be quite a bit easier to manage, technically, than your last assignment.

item.title: Assignment 04: Oral History
item.description: Due Date: March 24 Rather than repeat myself in my usual error-prone way, I will simply direct you to the assignment repository on Github. We will discuss this at great er length in class in the final weeks of the semester.

item.title: Assignment 05: Project Proposal
item.description: Table of Contents Call for Proposals: Digital History Initiative Grants Structure Expectations Due Date: April 05 For your final assignment, respond to the following call for proposals with an application approximately 2000 words in length, plus a provisional budget i n the form of a spreadsheet. See below for details. Call for Proposals: Digital History Initiative Grants The Hacking History Foundation is pleased to announce a new Digital History Initiative, intended to advance the field of digital historical studies in Canada.

item.title: Assignments 01 and 02: HTML & CSS self-study + Javascript Intro
item.description: Table of Contents Assignment Part I Due Date: Jan. 27 Part II Due Date: Feb. 09 You do not have to become a coder to do well in this course. However, you will have to be willing to explore technical skills that you might not otherwise develop as a humanities scholar. In this initial assignment, we’ll use one of the web’s many excellent self-education platforms to learn the very basics of how web pages work.

item.title: Digital History: His393, Winter 2018
item.description: Table of Contents Logistics Introduction Objectives Method Policies Tools Course Requirements & Grading Texts Course Outline Text, Code, and the Web Data Driven History Maps, Visualization, and History Oral History, Crowdsourcing, and the Promise of the Public Sphere Logistics Instructor: Matt Price Email: matt.price@utoronto.ca Office Hrs: SS 3077 T 1-2:30 Meeting Times F 3-5 Web: http://digital.
